comment.author: 73769698@N00
comment._content: This is probably Garcia Colorado. For more information go to www.slvdweller.com or lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/I?fsaall:5:./temp/~pp_rbCN::...

comment.author: 12386164@N02
comment._content: its costilla. Costilla and Garcia are the same town, but split by the colorado/New Mexico Border.

comment.author: 20927039@N07
comment._content: thats the plaza on the east side of 522. southeast of upper plaza road on 196.  its pretty neat using google earth street view and matching up the mountains in the background.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Sublime goddess:  Thank you for the information. We will update the information and reload the description.

comment.author: 38095024@N04
comment._content: Somebody splain the long chemtrail clouds in this photo from 1943.  No jets flying then right.  Not a normal cloud formation.  Methinks it was photoshopped in for some strange reason.  Perhaps so when people "look back"  they might "realize"'  that this crap has always been in the sky.  Shameful.

comment.author: 73769698@N00
comment._content: I still think it's Garcia Colorado, about 2 miles north of Costilla N.M. Here is a photo taken by Russell Lee in 1940: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/fsa.8b25646/ The clouds look natural to me, but there were several type of aircraft at the time that could have made contrails.

comment.author: 38095024@N04
comment._content: Anyone that reads this and is curious, if you have any old family photos (not digital images but actual photo prints) that depict the sky, take a gander.  No matter where you're from and how many pics you have, and not just from the 30s or 40s, I'll  be generous and give you up to say 1985, try and find multi-miles long thin linear clouds like these (like the ones all too common today) that seem to stretch from horizon to horizon.  You won't find them as they did not exist.  So again I wonder why they are showing up in digital versions of old photographs.
